http://www.autoblog.com/2011/03/14/report-chrysler-updates-imported-from-detroit-logo/ |title=Report: Chrysler updates 'Imported From Detroit' logo |date=March 14, 2011 |publisher=Autoblog.com |accessdate=March 18, 2016}} Following the Eminem ad, there was also an ad for Detroit Lions defensive tackle [[Ndamukong Suh]] driving a Chrysler 300 to Portland, Oregon, to visit his mother, an ad featuring Detroit-born fashion designer [[John Varvatos]] cruising through a shadowy Gotham while Kevin Yon's familiar baritone traces the designer's genesis.{{cite news|last=Schultz |first=Jonathan |url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/05/12/chrysler-exports-imported-from-detroit-to-new-york/ |title=Chrysler Exports 'Imported From Detroit' to New York |work=The New York Times |date=May 12, 2011 |accessdate=May 20, 2012}} In March 2011, Chrysler Group LLC filed a lawsuit against Moda Group LLC (owner of Pure Detroit clothing retailer) for copying and selling merchandise with the "Imported from Detroit" slogan.{{cite web|last=Halcom |first=Chad |date=March 16, 2011 |url= http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20110316/FREE/110319936/chrysler-sues-pure-detroit-says-imported-from-detroit-merchandise-infringes-on-trademark |title=Chrysler sues Pure Detroit, says 'Imported From Detroit' merchandise infringes on trademark |work=Crain's Detroit Business |accessdate=March 18, 2016}} Chrysler claimed it had notified defendant of its pending trademark application February 14, but the defendant argued Chrysler had not secured a trademark for the "Imported From Detroit" phrase. On June 18, 2011, U.S. District Judge Arthur Tarnow ruled that Chrysler's request did not show that it would suffer irreparable harm or that it had a strong likelihood of winning its case. Therefore, Pure Detroit's owner, Detroit retailer Moda Group LLC, can continue selling its "Imported from Detroit" products. Tarnow also noted that Chrysler does not have a trademark on "Imported from Detroit" and rejected the automaker's argument that trademark law is not applicable to the case.{{cite web|url=http://www.autoweek.com/article/20110629/CARNEWS/110629852/0/videonewsarchive |title=Chrysler loses 'Imported from Detroit' lawsuit |publisher=Autoweek.com |date=June 29, 2011 |accessdate=May 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614135955/http://www.autoweek.com/article/20110629/CARNEWS/110629852/0/videonewsarchive |archivedate=June 14, 2012 }}{{cite web|first=Zach|last=Bowman|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2011/06/29/chrysler-legal-bid-to-halt-imported-from-detroit-merchandise-s/ |title=Chrysler legal bid to halt 'Imported From Detroit' merchandise sales falls short |publisher=Autoblog.com |date=June 29, 2011 |accessdate=May 20, 2012}} In March 2012, Chrysler Group LLC and Pure Detroit agreed to a March 27 mediation to try to settle the lawsuit over the clothing company's use of "Imported from Detroit" slogan.{{cite web|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20120319/AUTO0101/203190378/1148/auto01/Chrysler-Pure-Detroit-agree-mediation-settle-Imported-from-Detroit-suit |title=Chrysler, Pure Detroit agree to mediation to settle 'Imported from Detroit' suit |work=The Detroit News |date=March 19, 2012 |accessdate=May 20, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Pure Detroit stated that Chrysler has made false claims about the origins of three vehicles - Chrysler 200, Chrysler 300 and Chrysler Town & Country - none of which are built in Detroit. Pure Detroit also said that Chrysler's Imported From Detroit merchandise is not being made in Detroit.{{Citation needed|date = July 2015}} In 2012 Chrysler and Pure Detroit came to an undisclosed settlement.{{cite web|url= http://www.mlive.com/auto/index.ssf/2012/04/chrysler_pure_detroit_reach_la.html|title=Chrysler, Pure Detroit reach lawsuit settlement over 'Imported from Detroit' slogan |website=MLive.com |access-date=2016-03-10}} Chrysler's [[Jefferson North Assembly]], which makes the Jeep Grand Cherokee and Dodge Durango, is the only car manufacturing plant of any company remaining entirely in Detroit (General Motors operates a plant which is partly in Detroit and partly in Hamtramck).{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/16/business/last-car-plant-brings-detroit-hope-and-cash.html |title=Last Car Plant Brings Detroit Hope and Cash |first=Bill |last=Vlasic |date=July 15, 2013 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=April 1, 2014}} In 2011, Eminem settled a lawsuit against [[Audi]] alleging the defendant had ripped off the Chrysler 300 Super Bowl commercial in the [[Audi A6]] Avant ad.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/industry/publishing/audi-settles-copyright-lawsuit-with-eminem-1005306352.story |title=Audi Settles Copyright Lawsuit With Eminem Over 'Lose Yourself' Ad |first=Wolfgang |last=Spahr |work=Billboard |date=August 5, 2011 |accessdate=April 29, 2012}} ===="Half Time in America"==== Again in 2012, Chrysler advertised during the [[Super Bowl]]. Its two-minute February 5, 2012 [[Super Bowl XLVI]] advertisement was titled "Half Time in America". The ad drew criticism from several leading U.S. [[Conservatism in the United States|conservatives]], who suggested that its messaging implied that President [[Barack Obama]] deserved a second term and, as such, was political payback for Obama's support for the federal bailout of the company.{{cite news |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2012-02-06/politics/politics_eastwood-ad-politics_1_chrysler-ad-halftime-show-america-auto-industry?_s=PM:POLITICS |first=Bryan |last=Monroe |publisher=CNN |title=Were politics buried inside Eastwood's 'Halftime' commercial? |date=February 6, 2012 |accessdate=April 29, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120624062810/http://articles.cnn.com/2012-02-06/politics/politics_eastwood-ad-politics_1_chrysler-ad-halftime-show-america-auto-industry?_s=PM%3APOLITICS |archivedate=June 24, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} Asked about the criticism in a ''[[60 Minutes]]'' interview with [[Steve Kroft]], Sergio Marchionne responded "just to rectify the record I paid back the loans at 19.7% Interest. 2010, Fiat Auto was planning to sell seven of its vehicles in the U.S. by 2014, while Fiat-controlled Chrysler Group was to supply nine models to sell under Fiat brands in the European market, according to a five-year plan rolled out on April 21, 2010 in [[Turin]], Italy, by Fiat and Chrysler CEO [[Sergio Marchionne]]. At least five of the Fiat Auto models were expected to be marketed in the U.S. under its [[Alfa Romeo]] brand. Showing the level of integration envisioned, a product introduction timeline envisaged Chrysler-built compact and full-size SUVs going on sale in 2012 and 2014, respectively, in both European and North American markets.{{cite news |url= https://www.usatoday.com/money/advertising/2010-04-21-fiat-splits_N.htm |work=USA Today |first=James R. |last=Healey |title=7 new Fiat models bound for U.S.; 9 Chryslers to go abroad |date=April 21, 2010}} ===Chrysler Uconnect=== First introduced as MyGig, Chrysler Uconnect is a system that brings interactive ability to the in-car radio and telemetric-like controls to car settings.{{cite web |url= http://www.allpar.com/history/chrysler-years/2009.html |title=2009 Chryslers, Dodges, and Jeeps: "Official" Changes |publisher=allpar |accessdate=April 1, 2014}} As of mid-2015, it is installed in hundreds of thousands of Fiat Chrysler vehicles.{{cite web|title=Hackers Remotely Kill a Jeep on the Highway—With Me in It|url= https://www.wired.com/2015/07/hackers-remotely-kill-jeep-highway/ |accessdate = 2015-07-22|website=Wired |last=Greenberg|first=Andy|date = }} It connects to the Internet via the mobile network of [[Sprint Corporation|Sprint]], providing the car with its own IP address. Internet connectivity using any Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep or Ram vehicle, via a Wi-Fi "hot-spot", is also available via [[Chrysler Uconnect Web|Uconnect Web]]. According to Chrysler LLC, the hotspot range extends approximately {{convert|100|ft|m}} from the vehicle in all directions, and combines both Wi-Fi and [[Sprint Corporation|Sprint's 3G]] cellular connectivity.{{Citation needed|date = July 2015}} Uconnect is available on several current{{When|date = July 2015}} and was available on several discontinued Chrysler models including the current Dodge Dart, [[Chrysler 300]], [[Chrysler Aspen|Aspen]], [[Chrysler Sebring|Sebring]], [[Chrysler Town and Country|Town and Country]], [[Dodge Avenger]], [[Dodge Caliber|Caliber]], [[Dodge Caravan|Grand Caravan]], [[Dodge Challenger|Challenger]], [[Dodge Charger (LX)|Charger]], [[Dodge Journey|Journey]], [[Dodge Nitro|Nitro]], and [[Dodge Ram|Ram]].{{cite web|last=Davies |first=Chris |date=June 26, 2008 |url= http://www.slashgear.com/chrysler-uconnect-web-turns-car-into-wifi-hotspot-2612280/ |title=Chrysler uconnect Web turns car into WiFi hotspot |publisher=SlashGear |accessdate=April 1, 2014}} In July 2015, IT security researchers announced a severe security flaw assumed to affect every Chrysler vehicle with Uconnect produced from late 2013 to early 2015. It allows hackers to gain access to the car over the Internet, and in the case of a [[Jeep Cherokee (KL)|Jeep Cherokee]] was demonstrated to enable an attacker to take control not just of the radio, A/C, and windshield wipers, but also of the car's steering, brakes and [[Transmission (mechanics)|transmission]]. Chrysler published a [[Patch (computing)|patch]] that car owners can download and install via a USB stick, or have a car dealer install for them. === Reception === Chrysler's quality and customer satisfaction ratings have been below average according to Consumer Reports and JD Powers since the late 1990s.{{cite news |title=Salvation At Chrysler, In the Form Of Fiat |last=Stewart |first=James |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 30, 2011 |accessdate=March 19, 2016 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/30/business/forced-marriage-of-fiat-and-chrysler-yields-success.html |quote=Quality was abysmal. Strategic Vision named Chrysler an overall winner in 2015 noting strong customer appeal and that with the rise in quality of all cars the difference between high and low "problem-counting" ratings are relatively small.{{cite news|last1=Rosevear|first1=John|title=Fiat Chrysler Finally Scores a Victory on Quality|url=http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2015/07/20/fiat-chrysler-finally-scores-a-victory-on-quality.aspx|accessdate=December 12, 2016|publisher=The Motley Fool|date=July 20, 2015}} ==Environmental Initiatives== Chrysler produced an experimental [[Battery electric vehicle|electric]] vehicle in 1979, the company developed [[Chrysler ETV-1]] electric prototype in cooperation with [[U.S. Department of Energy]]. In 1992, Chrysler developed the [[Dodge EPIC]] concept minivan. In 1993, Chrysler began to sell a limited-production electric minivan called the [[Chrysler TEVan|TEVan]]; however only 56 were produced. In 1997, a second generation, called the EPIC, was released. It was discontinued after 1999.{{Citation needed|date = July 2015}} Chrysler once owned the [[Global Electric Motorcars]] company, building low-speed [[neighborhood electric vehicles]], but sold GEM to [[Polaris Industries]] in 2011. In September 2007, Chrysler established [[Envi (Automobile)|ENVI]], an in-house organization focused on [[electric vehicle|electric-drive vehicles]] and related technologies which was disbanded by late 2009.{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/11/07/us-chrysler-ev-idUSTRE5A605N20091107?sp=true |title=Chrysler dismantles electric car plans under Fiat |date=November 6, 2009 |first=Kevin |last=Krolicki |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=April 1, 2014}} In August 2009, Chrysler took US$70 million in grants from the U.S. [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]] to develop a test fleet of 220 [[hybrid vehicle|hybrid]] pickup trucks and minivans. emissions credits|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-emissions-autos-idUSKBN0TZ2ZN20151216|accessdate=4 August 2017|agency=Reuters|date=16 Dec 2015}} ==Chrysler Defense== The dedicated tank building division of Chrysler, this division was founded as the Chrysler Tank division in 1940, originally with the intention of providing another production line for the [[M2 Medium Tank]], so that the U.S. Army could more rapidly build up its inventory of the type. Its first plant was the [[Detroit Arsenal (Warren, Michigan)|Detroit Arsenal Tank Plant]]. When the M2A1 was unexpectedly declared obsolete in August of the same year, plans were altered (though not without considerable difficulty) to produce the [[M3 Lee#Development|M3 Grant]] instead, primarily for the British as part of the United States under the counter support for Great Britain against Nazi Germany (the U.S. not yet being formally in the war), with the balance of the revised order going to the U.S. Army as the ''Lee''. After December 1941 and the United State's entry into the war against the Axis powers, the Tank division rapidly expanded, with new facilities such as the [[Packard Proving Grounds|Tank Arsenal Proving Ground]] at (then) [[Utica, Michigan]]. It also quickly widened the range of products it was developing and producing, including the [[M4 Sherman#U.S. design prototype|M4 Sherman tank]] and the [[Chrysler A57 multibank]] tank engine. {{see also|General Dynamics Land Systems}} ==Special programs== During World War II, essentially all of Chrysler's facilities were devoted to building military vehicles (the [[Jeep]] brand came later, after Chrysler acquired [[American Motors Corporation]]).{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_djEK2wqmAIC&pg=PA192&dq=Multi-auto+Tank+Engine+Designed+and+Developed+by+Central+Engineering |page=192 |title=The Birth of Chrysler Corporation and Its Engineering Legacy |first=Carl |last=Breer |first2=Anthony J. |last2=Yanik |year=1992 |publisher= SAE International |isbn=978-1-56091-524-9 |accessdate=April 28, 2012}} They were also designing V12 and V16 hemi-engines producing {{convert|2500|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} for airplanes, but they did not make it into production as [[jet engine|jets]] were developed and were seen as the future for air travel.{{cite web |url=http://www.allpar.com/mopar/hemi/chrysler-hemi.html |title=The Original Chrysler Hemi Engine |publisher=Allpar.com |accessdate=April 28, 2012}} During the 1950s [[Cold War]] period, Chrysler made [[Chrysler air raid siren|air raid sirens]] powered by its Hemi V-8 engines. ===Radar antennas=== When the [[Radiation Laboratory]] at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] was established in 1941 to develop [[microwave radar]]s, one of the first projects resulted in the [[SCR-584]], the most widely recognized radar system of the war era. This system included a [[parabolic antenna]] six feet in diameter that was mechanically aimed in a helical pattern (round and round as well as up and down). One of Chrysler's most significant contributions to the war effort was not in the field of vehicles but in the radar field. For the final production design of this antenna and its highly complex drive mechanism, the Army's [[Signal Corps Laboratories]] turned to Chrysler's Central Engineering Office. There, the parabola was changed from aluminum to steel, allowing production forming using standard automotive presses. To keep weight down, 6,000 equally spaced holes were drilled in the face (this had no effect on the radiation pattern). The drive mechanism was completely redesigned, using technology derived from Chrysler's research in automotive gears and differentials. The changes resulted in improved performance, reduced weight, and easier maintenance. A large portion of the Dodge plant was used in building 1,500 of the SCR-584 antennas as well as the vans used in the systems.{{cite book |last=Stout |first=Wesley W. |title=The Great Detective |publisher=Chrysler Corporation |year=1946}}{{citation |last=Colton |first=Roger B. |title=Radar in the United States Army |publisher=Proceedings of the I.R.E. |volume=33 |pages=740–753 |year=1947 |url=http://cecom.army.mil/historian/docdisp.php?fname=RadarintheUSArmy_byRogerColton.pdf&dirname=Radar |accessdate=April 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625022825/http://cecom.army.mil/historian/docdisp.php?fname=RadarintheUSArmy_byRogerColton.pdf&dirname=Radar |archivedate=June 25, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} ===Aircraft=== * [[Chrysler VZ-6]] ===Missiles=== In April 1950, the U.S. Army established the Ordnance Guided Missile Center (OGMC) at [[Redstone Arsenal]], adjacent to [[Huntsville, Alabama]]. To form OGMC, over 1,000 civilian and military personnel were transferred from [[Fort Bliss, Texas]]. Included was a group of German scientists and engineers led by [[Wernher von Braun]]; this group had been brought to America under [[Project Paperclip]]. OGMC designed the Army's first [[short-range ballistic missile]], the [[PGM-11 Redstone]], based on the WWII German [[V-2]] missile. Chrysler established the Missile Division to serve as the Redstone prime contractor, setting up an engineering operation in Huntsville and for production obtaining use from the U.S. Navy of a large plant in [[Sterling Heights, Michigan]]. The Redstone was in active service from 1958 to 1964; it was also the first missile to test-launch a live [[nuclear weapon]], first detonated in a 1958 test in the South Pacific.Bullard, John W.; "History Of The Redstone Missile System," Historical Monograph Project Number: AMC 23 M. Historical Division, Army Missile Command Working together, the Missile Division and von Braun's team greatly increased the capability of the Redstone, resulting in the [[PGM-19 Jupiter]], a [[medium-range ballistic missile]]. In May 1959, a Jupiter missile launched two small monkeys into space in a [[nose cone]]; this was America's first successful flight and recovery of live space payloads. Responsibility for deploying Jupiter missiles was transferred from the Army to the Air Force; armed with [[nuclear warheads]], they were first deployed in [[Italy]] and [[Turkey]] during the early 1960s.{{cite web|title=Fact Sheet: Chrysler SM-78/PGM-19 Jupiter |publisher=National Museum of the U.S. Air Force |url=http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=534 |date=May 14, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407094736/http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=534 |archivedate=April 7, 2014 }} ===Space boosters=== In July 1959, [[NASA]] chose the [[Redstone missile]] as the basis for the [[Mercury-Redstone Launch Vehicle]] to be used for suborbital test flights of the [[Project Mercury]] spacecraft. Three unmanned MRLV launch attempts were made between November 1960 and March 1961, two of which were successful. The MRLV successfully launched the chimpanzee [[Ham the Chimp|Ham]], and astronauts [[Alan Shepard]] and [[Gus Grissom]] on three suborbital flights in January, May and July 1961, respectively. America's more ambitious manned space travel plans included the design of the [[Saturn (rocket family)|Saturn series]] of heavy-lift launch vehicles by a team headed by [[Wernher von Braun]]. Chrysler's Huntsville operation, then designated the Space Division, became [[Marshall Space Flight Center]]'s prime contractor for the first stage of the [[Saturn I]] and [[Saturn IB]] versions. The design was based on a cluster of Redstone and [[PGM-19 Jupiter|Jupiter]] fuel tanks, and Chrysler built it for the [[Apollo program]] in the [[Michoud Assembly Facility]] in East New Orleans, one of the largest manufacturing plants in the world. Between October 1961 and July 1975, NASA used ten Saturn Is and nine Saturn IBs for suborbital and orbital flights, all of which were successful;{{cite book|last=Bilstein |first=Roger E. |url= https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4206/sp4206.htm |title=Stages to Saturn: A Technological History of the Apollo/Saturn Launch Vehicles NASA SP-4206 |year=1980 |isbn=0-16-048909-1 |accessdate=March 18, 2016}}{{Page needed|date=August 2012}} Chrysler missiles and boosters never suffered a launch failure.{{Citation needed|date=August 2012}} The division was also a subcontractor which modified one of the [[Mobile Launcher Platform]]s for use with the Saturn IB rockets using Saturn V infrastructure. ==Discontinued brands== * [[Chrysler Europe]] (sold to [[Peugeot]]) ** [[Rootes Group]], UK *** [[Sunbeam Motor Car Company|Sunbeam]] (1901–1976), UK *** [[Humber Limited|Humber]] (1898–1976), UK *** [[Singer (car)|Singer]] (1905–1970), UK *** [[Commer]] (1905–1979), UK *** [[Hillman]] (1907–1976), UK *** [[Karrier]] (1908–1977), UK ** [[Simca]] (1934–1977), France ** [[Barreiros (manufacturer)|Barreiros]] (1959–1978), Spain * [[American Motors Corporation]] (AMC) (1954–1988), US ** [[Hudson Motor Car Company|Hudson]] (1909–1957), US ** [[Nash Motors|Nash]] (1917–1957), US ** [[Rambler (automobile)|Rambler]] (1900–1914;
